{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3527615,"name":"Vincent Banks","username":"v0ncent","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/v0ncent/{size}/258352_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-15T01:30:01.149Z","cooked":"

Hello HeadMan Delphi Community,

as my title states I have a few questions about these specified methods in the Phoenix 6 Swerve Library:

   /**
     * Adds a vision measurement to the Kalman Filter. This will correct the
     * odometry pose estimate
     * while still accounting for measurement noise.
     *
     * @param visionRobotPoseMeters The pose of the robot as measured by the vision
     *                              camera.
     * @param timestampSeconds      The timestamp of the vision measurement in
     *                              seconds.
     */
    @Override
    public void addVisionMeasurement(Pose2d visionRobotPoseMeters, double timestampSeconds) {
        super.addVisionMeasurement(visionRobotPoseMeters, Utils.fpgaToCurrentTime(timestampSeconds));
    }

    /**
     * Adds a vision measurement to the Kalman Filter. This will correct the
     * odometry pose estimate
     * while still accounting for measurement noise.
     * <p>
     * Note that the vision measurement standard deviations passed into this method
     * will continue to apply to future measurements until a subsequent call to
     * {@link #setVisionMeasurementStdDevs(Matrix)} or this method.
     *
     * @param visionRobotPoseMeters    The pose of the robot as measured by the
     *                                 vision camera.
     * @param timestampSeconds         The timestamp of the vision measurement in
     *                                 seconds.
     * @param visionMeasurementStdDevs Standard deviations of the vision pose
     *                                 measurement
     *                                 in the form [x, y, theta]ᵀ, with units in
     *                                 meters and radians.
     */
    @Override
    public void addVisionMeasurement(
            Pose2d visionRobotPoseMeters,
            double timestampSeconds,
            Matrix<N3, N1> visionMeasurementStdDevs) {
        super.addVisionMeasurement(visionRobotPoseMeters, Utils.fpgaToCurrentTime(timestampSeconds),
                visionMeasurementStdDevs);
    }

The questions I have are:

  1. What do they mean by “Trust vision measurement less” ?
  2. My initial thoughts when I saw these methods was “wow if you had full 360 vision coverage around your robot, you could easily estimate your exact position on the field” but then upon reading further documentation they say this “To promote stability of the pose estimate and make it robust to bad vision data, we recommend only adding vision measurements that are already within one meter or so of the current pose estimate.”. Does this make that idea not feasible or am I overthinking this?
  3. Is it recommended to provide standard deviation matrix vs not providing it.

any wisdom on the topic is appreciated. Thanks!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-02-15T01:30:01.149Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":50,"reads":121,"readers_count":120,"score":274.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":491766,"topic_slug":"phoenix-6-swerve-addvisionmeasurement-questions","display_username":"Vincent Banks","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56270,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/phoenix-6-swerve-addvisionmeasurement-questions/491766/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3537174,"name":null,"username":"anon74528069","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/46a35a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-23T15:51:03.316Z","cooked":"

Hello!

  1. You can decide to trust more or less the vision measurements depending on how much noise your camera gets, so the more noise your camera has, the less you want to trust the results it feeds you.
  2. I think it would be very difficult to have 360 vision, since the tags are fairly far away from one another, except the reef. Also, depending on how much you decide to trust your vision and which coprocessor you have, only one/two cameras are very good. (we have one limelight 3 and one limelight 2+, but we mainly use the 3 and have a very accurate pose estimation)
  3. we personally provide one, and i think it would be better since it indicates how much vision results can fluctuate and the matrix limits what you accept in your estimation versus what is acceptable.

p-s i may not be the best reference since this is my first year working on vision, but this is my take on it. feel free to do more research!

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-02-23T15:51:03.316Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":84,"readers_count":83,"score":21.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":491766,"topic_slug":"phoenix-6-swerve-addvisionmeasurement-questions","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64292,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_suspended":true,"post_url":"/t/phoenix-6-swerve-addvisionmeasurement-questions/491766/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3538158,"name":"Jackson Elia","username":"Traptricker","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/traptricker/{size}/215403_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-24T17:08:38.040Z","cooked":"
  1. What do they mean by “Trust vision measurement less” ?

The pose estimator does a bunch of fancy math behind the scenes to “fuse” together multiple sources of pose measurements. This usually means using measurements from your swerve, and vision measurements from your cameras reading april tags. You can choose how much each source of measurements affects the pose estimation, and this is done with standard deviations. So if you trust the measurements a lot, you give them a relatively low standard deviation → the pose estimator will be more affected by this measurement.

For example, you it is generally agreed that you should trust your swerve more than your vision, (my team does [0.03, 0.03, 1 degree] for swerve, [0.5, 0.5, 50 degrees] for vision) so give your swerve measurements lower standard deviations than your vision measurements. **The exception to this might be unless your vision measurement is really close to the april tag and thus really accurate, then you could lower them. My team variably trusts our vision measurements more or less if we’re closer or further away from april tags.

My initial thoughts when I saw these methods was “wow if you had full 360 vision coverage around your robot, you could easily estimate your exact position on the field”

If you had 360 vision coverage and you only added vision measurements when you were really confident they were correct, then this would definitely work. However, I would prioritize thinking about where you put your cameras more than covering 360 degrees. My team has 2 cameras, but we are making sure they will be able to see the reef april tags while scoring, and the feeder station april tags while intaking.

Is it recommended to provide standard deviation matrix vs not providing it.

I would recommend it. Remember, the units of the matrix are what the units of your measurements are in, so for my team is [meters, meters, radians]

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-02-24T17:08:38.040Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":66,"readers_count":65,"score":18.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":491766,"topic_slug":"phoenix-6-swerve-addvisionmeasurement-questions","display_username":"Jackson Elia","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53032,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4829 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/phoenix-6-swerve-addvisionmeasurement-questions/491766/3","custom_user_title":"4829 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3538176,"name":"Justin Buist","username":"Justin_Buist","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/c77e96/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-24T17:24:45.251Z","cooked":"

Others have covered the ‘trust vision less’ thing – you just give it wider standard deviations. I think we’ve found 0.4 meters on x/y is about right this year. I forget rotation and I don’t trust my value anyway so I won’t say what it is.

In the past we’ve done things where we scale the standard deviations out, make them bigger, when the robot is moving faster, but didn’t find that helpful this year. It made things worse.

We are trying to make sure all of our pathing has the front of the robot, where the cameras are, facing the reef. That seems to provide good targeting. Dropping a camera that’s facing rear would also be nice for player stations but, honestly, we’re seeing great results in the lab just with one camera properly mounted on the swerve module and another taped to a weight in the middle of the bot that has 30% of its view obstructed. I think with two cameras up front and a dedicated effort to keep them at the reef things will go pretty smooth.
